canonical_explanation.text: Resistors can be combined in series or parallel. In series, the same current flows through all resistors and Rs = R1 + R2 + R3. Voltage divides in proportion to resistance. In parallel, the same voltage appears across all resistors and 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3. Current divides inversely to resistance. A cell has internal resistance r, and EMF = V + Ir, where V is terminal voltage. When current flows, V = E - Ir. The current in circuit is I = E/(R + r) where R is external resistance.
rules: Series combination: same current through all resistors
Parallel combination: same voltage across all resistors
Parallel equivalent is always less than smallest resistance
For two resistors in parallel: Rp = (R1 x R2)/(R1 + R2)

questions.question_text: In a series combination of resistors, the current is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a series combination of resistors, the same current flows through each resistor. This is because the current has no other path to flow through, so it has to be the same in all parts of the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because in a series combination, the current is the same through each resistor. This is because the current has no other path to flow through, and it has to be the same in all parts of the circuit. The current is not different, zero, or maximum through the smallest resistor in a series combination.

questions.question_text: The equivalent resistance of resistors in series is:
questions.explanation_correct: The equivalent resistance of resistors in series is the sum of all the individual resistances. This is because the same current flows through each resistor in a series circuit, and the total resistance is the addition of all the individual resistances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equivalent resistance of resistors in series is not less than the smallest resistor, nor is it equal to the smallest resistor. It is also not the product of all the resistances. The correct option is that the equivalent resistance of resistors in series is the sum of all the individual resistances, as the same current flows through each resistor in a series circuit.

questions.question_text: In a parallel combination of resistors, the voltage is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel combination of resistors, the voltage is the same across each resistor. This is because all the resistors are connected to the same voltage source, so the voltage must be the same across each one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) The voltage is the same across each resistor in a parallel combination. This is because all the resistors are connected to the same voltage source, so the voltage must be the same across each one. The voltage is not different across each resistor (option A), it is not zero across each resistor (option C), and it is not maximum across the largest resistor (option D).

questions.question_text: The equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is:
questions.explanation_correct: The equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is less than the smallest resistor. This is because the current divides inversely to the resistance, so the path with the smallest resistance carries the most current, lowering the overall resistance of the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is not the sum or average of all the resistances. It is calculated as the reciprocal of the sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistances. This gives a value that is less than the smallest resistor, as the current divides and flows through the paths of least resistance.

questions.question_text: Three resistors of 2 ohms, 3 ohms, and 5 ohms are connected in series. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 10 ohms. In a series circuit, the equivalent resistance is the sum of all the individual resistor values. Since the three resistors are 2 ohms, 3 ohms, and 5 ohms, the total equivalent resistance is 2 + 3 + 5 = 10 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not represent the sum of the individual resistor values in a series circuit. Option A) 0.97 ohms is too low, Option B) 3.33 ohms is also too low, and Option D) 30 ohms is too high. The correct answer is 10 ohms, which is the sum of the three resistor values of 2 ohms, 3 ohms, and 5 ohms.

questions.question_text: Two resistors of 4 ohms and 6 ohms are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: When two resistors are connected in parallel, the equivalent resistance is calculated using the formula 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2, where R1 and R2 are the individual resistor values. Plugging in the given values of 4 ohms and 6 ohms, we get 1/Rp = 1/4 + 1/6, which simplifies to 1/Rp = 5/12, or Rp = 2.4 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly apply the formula for equivalent resistance in a parallel circuit. Option A (10 ohms) is the sum of the individual resistor values, which is the formula for equivalent resistance in a series circuit. Options C (5 ohms) and D (1.5 ohms) do not properly use the parallel resistance formula of 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2.

questions.question_text: Three 6 ohm resistors are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: When three 6 ohm resistors are connected in parallel, the equivalent resistance is calculated as 1/Req = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3, which gives 1/Req = 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 = 1/2 or Req = 2 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options can be explained as follows: Option A (18 ohms) is wrong because when resistors are connected in parallel, the equivalent resistance is less than the individual resistor values. Option B (6 ohms) is wrong because it is the same as the individual resistor value, which is not the case for a parallel combination. Option D (3 ohms) is wrong because the equivalent resistance of three 6 ohm resistors in parallel is 2 ohms, not 3 ohms.

questions.question_text: Internal resistance of a cell causes:

options.text: Decrease in terminal voltage when current flows

questions.explanation_correct: The internal resistance of a cell causes a decrease in the terminal voltage when current flows through the cell. This is because the voltage drop across the internal resistance reduces the voltage available at the terminals of the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The internal resistance of a cell does not cause an increase in the EMF or the current in the circuit. Instead, it causes a decrease in the terminal voltage when current flows through the cell. This is because the voltage drop across the internal resistance reduces the voltage available at the terminals of the cell.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit with resistors 2 ohm and 3 ohm connected to 10 V, the current is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all resistors. To find the current, we can use the formula V = IR, where V is the total voltage, I is the current, and R is the total resistance. With resistors of 2 ohm and 3 ohm, the total resistance is 2 + 3 = 5 ohm. Plugging in the values, we get I = 10 V / 5 ohm = 2 A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not follow the formula for finding the current in a series circuit. Option A (5 A) is too high, Option C (3.33 A) is too high, and Option D (0.5 A) is too low. The correct current is 2 A, as calculated using the formula V = IR and the given resistor values.

questions.question_text: A 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistor are in series, and this combination is in parallel with a 3 ohm resistor. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 2.25 ohms. When resistors are in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances. So the series combination of 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistors has a total resistance of 9 ohms. This series combination is then in parallel with the 3 ohm resistor, so the equivalent resistance is 1/(1/9 + 1/3) = 2.25 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not account for the resistors being in both series and parallel combinations. Option B) 4.5 ohms is the total resistance of just the series combination, not the full parallel-series combination. Option C) 12 ohms is the total of all the resistors added together, without considering the parallel connection. Option D) 1.5 ohms is incorrect because it does not match the actual calculated equivalent resistance of 2.25 ohms.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit, the voltage across a resistor is proportional to its:
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the voltage across each resistor is proportional to its resistance. This is because the same current flows through all the resistors, and the voltage drop across each resistor is determined by the product of the current and the resistance, as per Ohm's law (V = IR).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The voltage across a resistor in a series circuit is not proportional to the current, power, or conductance of the resistor. Instead, it is proportional to the resistance of the resistor. This is because the same current flows through all the resistors in a series circuit, and the voltage drop across each resistor is determined by the product of the current and the resistance, as per Ohm's law (V = IR).

questions.question_text: In a parallel circuit, current through a resistor is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the current through each resistor is inversely proportional to its resistance. This means that the resistor with lower resistance will have more current flowing through it compared to the resistor with higher resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The current in a parallel circuit does not flow equally through all the resistors. Instead, the current divides up among the resistors in inverse proportion to their resistances. The resistor with lower resistance will have more current flowing through it, while the resistor with higher resistance will have less current.

questions.question_text: A cell of EMF 3 V and internal resistance 1 ohm is connected to a 5 ohm resistor. The terminal voltage is:
questions.explanation_correct: The terminal voltage of the cell is given by the formula V = E - Ir, where E is the EMF of the cell, I is the current in the circuit, and r is the internal resistance. With E = 3V, r = 1 ohm, and a 5 ohm resistor, the terminal voltage is 2.5V.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (3V) is incorrect because the terminal voltage is less than the EMF due to the internal resistance of the cell. Option C (0.5V) is incorrect because the terminal voltage cannot be less than the internal voltage drop. Option D (2V) is incorrect because the formula V = E - Ir gives the correct terminal voltage of 2.5V.

questions.question_text: A cell of EMF 2 V and internal resistance 0.5 ohm delivers maximum power when external resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 0.5 ohm. This is because when the external resistance is equal to the internal resistance of the cell, the cell delivers maximum power to the external circuit. In this case, the internal resistance is 0.5 ohm, so the maximum power is delivered when the external resistance is also 0.5 ohm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not satisfy the condition for maximum power transfer. Option A) 0 ohm is incorrect because when the external resistance is zero, the current in the circuit will be very high, leading to a low terminal voltage and low power output. Option C) 1 ohm is incorrect because it is not equal to the internal resistance of 0.5 ohm. Option D) Infinite is incorrect because an infinite resistance means no current flows, so no power is delivered to the external circuit.

questions.question_text: Two 4 ohm resistors in parallel are in series with a 2 ohm resistor. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 4 ohms. When two 4 ohm resistors are in parallel, the equivalent resistance is 2 ohms (1/R_p = 1/4 + 1/4 = 1/2). This 2 ohm resistor is then in series with a 2 ohm resistor, making the total equivalent resistance 4 ohms (R_s = 2 + 2 = 4).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Option B) 6 ohms is wrong because the parallel combination of two 4 ohm resistors is 2 ohms, not 4 ohms. Option C) 10 ohms is wrong because the series combination of 2 ohms and 2 ohms is 4 ohms, not 10 ohms. Option D) 1.33 ohms is wrong because the parallel combination of two 4 ohm resistors is 2 ohms, not 1.33 ohms.

questions.question_text: The main disadvantage of series circuit for household wiring is:

options.text: If one device fails, all stop working

questions.explanation_correct: The main disadvantage of a series circuit for household wiring is that if one device fails, all devices stop working. This is because in a series circuit, the current is the same through all the resistors, so if one device stops working, the entire circuit is broken.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main disadvantage of a series circuit is not that it uses more wire, consumes more power, or costs more. In a series circuit, the current is the same through all the resistors, so if one device stops working, the entire circuit is broken. This is the key disadvantage for household wiring, as it means that if one device fails, all the other devices will also stop working.

questions.question_text: Household appliances are connected in parallel because:
questions.explanation_correct: Household appliances are connected in parallel because each appliance gets the same voltage, allowing them to operate independently. This is because in a parallel circuit, the same voltage appears across all the resistors (or appliances).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Connecting household appliances in parallel does not save electricity, use less wire, or increase total resistance. In a parallel circuit, the current divides inversely proportional to the resistance of each appliance, allowing them to operate at the same voltage. This is the key reason why household appliances are connected in parallel.

questions.question_text: If n identical resistors of resistance R each are connected in series, the equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: When n identical resistors are connected in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances. Since all the resistors have the same resistance R, the total resistance is n times the individual resistance, which is nR.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly represent the relationship between the number of resistors and the total resistance in a series circuit. Option A would be the total resistance if the resistors were connected in parallel, not series. Option C is the resistance of a single resistor, not the total resistance of n resistors in series. Option D is the square of the total resistance, which does not accurately represent the series connection.

questions.question_text: If n identical resistors of resistance R each are connected in parallel, the equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: When n identical resistors are connected in parallel, the total resistance is reduced by a factor of n. The formula for equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ... + 1/Rn. For n identical resistors, this simplifies to 1/Rp = n/R, so the equivalent resistance is R/n.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (nR) is incorrect because the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is always less than the resistance of a single resistor. Option C (R) is incorrect because the equivalent resistance decreases as more resistors are connected in parallel. Option D (n^2R) is incorrect because the equivalent resistance is inversely proportional to the number of resistors, not proportional to the square of the number of resistors.

questions.question_text: Three resistors of 3 ohms each are connected. The maximum resistance that can be obtained is:
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum resistance that can be obtained is 9 ohms (option A) because three resistors of 3 ohms each connected in series will have a total resistance of 3 + 3 + 3 = 9 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: Option B (1 ohm) is the minimum resistance that can be obtained when the three resistors are connected in parallel, Option C (3 ohms) is the resistance of each individual resistor, and Option D (6 ohms) is not the correct answer as it does not represent the maximum resistance when the resistors are connected in series.

questions.question_text: Three resistors of 3 ohms each are connected. The minimum resistance that can be obtained is:
questions.explanation_correct: The minimum resistance that can be obtained is 1 ohm, when the three 3-ohm resistors are connected in parallel. In a parallel circuit, the total resistance is the reciprocal of the sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistances, which is 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 = 1 ohm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (9 ohms) is incorrect because the three 3-ohm resistors connected in series would result in a total resistance of 3 + 3 + 3 = 9 ohms. Option C (3 ohms) is incorrect because it is the individual resistance of each resistor, not the combined resistance. Option D (0.33 ohms) is incorrect because it is the reciprocal of the total resistance, not the total resistance itself.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit of 2 ohm and 4 ohm resistors with 12 V supply, the voltage across 4 ohm is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all resistors. Since the total resistance is 2 ohm + 4 ohm = 6 ohm, and the voltage supply is 12 V, the voltage across the 4 ohm resistor is 4 V (4 ohm / 6 ohm * 12 V).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The voltage across the 4 ohm resistor in a series circuit is not 4 V, 6 V, or 12 V. The correct voltage is 8 V, which is calculated by the proportion of the resistor values (4 ohm / 6 ohm * 12 V).

questions.question_text: In a parallel circuit with 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistors and 12 V supply, the current through 3 ohm is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the current through each resistor is inversely proportional to its resistance. Since the resistors are 3 ohm and 6 ohm, the current through the 3 ohm resistor will be twice the current through the 6 ohm resistor. With a 12 V supply, the total current in the parallel circuit will be 4 A, so the current through the 3 ohm resistor is 4 A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly apply the principles of parallel circuits. Option A (2 A) is too low because the total current in the parallel circuit is 4 A. Option C (6 A) is too high because the total current cannot exceed 4 A. Option D (1 A) is too low because the current through the 3 ohm resistor must be higher than the current through the 6 ohm resistor.

questions.question_text: The formula for current in a circuit with EMF E, external resistance R and internal resistance r is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct formula is I = E/(R + r) because when current flows in a circuit, the voltage drop across the internal resistance r of the cell reduces the terminal voltage to E - Ir, and the total resistance in the circuit is the sum of the external resistance R and the internal resistance r.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option C, I = E/(R + r), is the correct formula. This is because the total resistance in the circuit is the sum of the external resistance R and the internal resistance r of the cell. The internal resistance r reduces the terminal voltage to E - Ir, and the current in the circuit is determined by the total resistance R + r.

questions.question_text: For two resistors R1 and R2 in parallel, the equivalent resistance formula is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct formula for equivalent resistance of two resistors R1 and R2 in parallel is (R1 x R2)/(R1 + R2). This is because the reciprocal of the equivalent resistance is the sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistances, which gives the formula (1/R1 + 1/R2) = 1/Req.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not the correct formula for equivalent resistance in parallel. Option A, (R1 + R2), is the formula for resistance in series, not parallel. Option C, (R1 - R2), is not a valid formula for equivalent resistance. Option D, (R1/R2), does not correctly combine the resistances in parallel.

questions.question_text: A 2 ohm resistor is in series with a parallel combination of 3 ohm and 6 ohm. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 4 ohms. When a 2 ohm resistor is in series with a parallel combination of 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistors, the equivalent resistance is the sum of the series resistors, which is 2 ohms plus the equivalent resistance of the parallel combination, which is 2 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is B) 11 ohms. This is incorrect because the equivalent resistance of the parallel combination of 3 ohm and 6 ohm resistors is 2 ohms, and when this is added in series with the 2 ohm resistor, the total equivalent resistance is 4 ohms, not 11 ohms.

questions.question_text: When a cell is short-circuited (R = 0), the current is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a cell is short-circuited, the external resistance R becomes zero. In this case, the current in the circuit is maximum and is equal to the cell's EMF (E) divided by its internal resistance (r), as per the formula I = E/(R + r).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The current in a short-circuited cell is not infinite, as that would require the internal resistance r to be zero, which is not possible. The correct answer is that the current is maximum and is equal to E/r, as the external resistance R is zero in a short circuit.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit, if one resistor is removed:
questions.explanation_correct: If one resistor is removed from a series circuit, the current path is broken, and the current becomes zero. This is because in a series circuit, the same current flows through all resistors, and if one resistor is removed, the circuit is no longer complete, and no current can flow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options would not be correct because in a series circuit, the current is the same through all resistors. Removing one resistor would break the circuit, causing the current to become zero, not increase, decrease, or remain the same.

questions.question_text: In a parallel circuit, if one resistor is removed:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, when one resistor is removed, the total resistance of the circuit decreases. This means the total current flowing through the circuit will also decrease, as the current is inversely proportional to the resistance (I = V/R).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because when a resistor is removed from a parallel circuit, the total resistance of the circuit decreases. This means the total current flowing through the circuit will also decrease, not increase. Option C is incorrect because the total current does not become zero, as the remaining resistors will still allow current to flow through the circuit. Option D is incorrect because the voltage across the parallel resistors remains the same even if one resistor is removed.

questions.question_text: Terminal voltage equals EMF when:
questions.explanation_correct: The terminal voltage equals the EMF (electromotive force) when there is no current flowing in the circuit, i.e., in an open circuit. This is because with no current, there is no voltage drop across the internal resistance of the cell, and the terminal voltage is equal to the EMF.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The terminal voltage does not equal the EMF when maximum current flows (option A) because the voltage drop across the internal resistance would be high, reducing the terminal voltage. The terminal voltage also does not equal the EMF when the internal resistance is maximum (option C) or the external resistance is zero (option D), as there would still be a voltage drop across the internal resistance.

questions.question_text: In series combination, total resistance is always greater than any individual resistance.
questions.explanation_correct: In a series combination, the total resistance is the sum of all the individual resistances. Since all resistors have a positive value, the total resistance will always be greater than any individual resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. In a series combination, the total resistance is the sum of all the individual resistances. This means that the total resistance will always be greater than any individual resistance, as each resistance contributes to the overall resistance in the circuit.

questions.question_text: In parallel combination, total resistance is always less than the smallest resistance.
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel combination of resistors, the total resistance is always less than the smallest resistance. This is because the current divides inversely to the resistance, and the paths with lower resistance will carry more current, effectively reducing the overall resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. In a parallel combination, the total resistance is always less than the individual resistor values. This is because the current divides among the parallel paths, and the paths with lower resistance will carry more current. Therefore, the total resistance is lower than the smallest resistance in the combination.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit, voltage is same across all resistors.
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all the resistors. However, the voltage across each resistor is different and is proportional to the resistance of that resistor. This is because the total voltage applied across the series circuit gets divided among the resistors based on their resistance values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that voltage is the same across all resistors in a series circuit is incorrect. This is because the total voltage applied across the series circuit gets divided among the resistors based on their resistance values. The voltage across each resistor is proportional to the resistance of that resistor, and hence, the voltage is not the same across all resistors in a series circuit.

questions.question_text: In a parallel circuit, current is same through all resistors.
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the current divides among the different resistors in inverse proportion to their resistance values. This means the current is not the same through all the resistors, but rather it distributes based on their resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect statement assumes that the current is the same through all resistors in a parallel circuit. However, this is not true. In a parallel circuit, the current divides among the different resistors based on their resistance values, with more current flowing through the lower resistance paths. So the current is not the same through all resistors in a parallel circuit.

questions.question_text: Internal resistance of an ideal cell is zero.
questions.explanation_correct: The internal resistance of an ideal cell is zero. An ideal cell is a theoretical concept where the cell has no internal resistance, meaning the entire voltage produced by the cell is available at the terminals. This is because an ideal cell has no dissipation of energy within the cell itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The internal resistance of a real cell is not zero. In a real cell, there is some resistance within the cell itself, which is called the internal resistance. This internal resistance is present due to the materials and construction of the cell, and it causes a voltage drop inside the cell when current flows. Therefore, the terminal voltage of a real cell is less than the electromotive force (EMF) of the cell by an amount equal to the product of the current and the internal resistance.

questions.question_text: Adding more resistors in parallel decreases total resistance.
questions.explanation_correct: Adding more resistors in parallel decreases the total resistance because the reciprocal of the total resistance (1/Rp) is the sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistors (1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3). As more resistors are added, the sum of the reciprocals increases, making the total resistance lower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect belief is that adding more resistors in parallel increases the total resistance. This is not true because as you add more parallel resistors, the total resistance decreases. The total resistance in a parallel circuit is always less than the resistance of the smallest individual resistor, and adding more resistors makes the total resistance even smaller.

questions.question_text: Adding more resistors in series increases total resistance.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, adding more resistors in series increases the total resistance. This is because the total resistance in a series circuit is the sum of the individual resistor values (Rs = R1 + R2 + R3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that adding more resistors in series decreases the total resistance. This is a common misconception, but it is not correct. In a series circuit, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistor values, so adding more resistors will increase the total resistance.

questions.question_text: Two 4 ohm resistors in series have the same resistance as four 4 ohm resistors in parallel.
questions.explanation_correct: The resistance of two 4 ohm resistors in series is 4 + 4 = 8 ohms, while the resistance of four 4 ohm resistors in parallel is 1/(1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4) = 1 ohm. So the two resistance combinations are not the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect statement assumes that two resistors in series have the same resistance as four resistors in parallel. This is not true, as the resistance in series adds up, while the resistance in parallel decreases according to the formula 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3. In this case, the series resistance is 8 ohms, while the parallel resistance is 1 ohm, which are clearly not the same.

questions.question_text: EMF is always greater than or equal to terminal voltage.
questions.explanation_correct: The EMF of a cell is always greater than or equal to the terminal voltage. This is because when current flows through the cell, there is a voltage drop across the internal resistance of the cell, which reduces the terminal voltage compared to the EMF.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'EMF is always greater than or equal to terminal voltage' is correct. When current flows through a cell, there is a voltage drop across the internal resistance of the cell. This means that the terminal voltage is less than the EMF of the cell. The terminal voltage is given by the equation V = E - Ir, where V is the terminal voltage, E is the EMF of the cell, I is the current, and r is the internal resistance of the cell.

questions.question_text: To get equivalent resistance of 2 ohms from two 4 ohm resistors, connect them in parallel.
questions.explanation_correct: To get an equivalent resistance of 2 ohms from two 4 ohm resistors, you need to connect them in parallel. The formula for equivalent resistance in parallel is 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2, where Rp is the parallel resistance. Plugging in the values, we get 1/Rp = 1/4 + 1/4 = 1/2, so Rp = 2 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Connecting two 4 ohm resistors in series would give an equivalent resistance of 8 ohms, not 2 ohms. In series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances. To get an equivalent resistance of 2 ohms, you need to connect the two 4 ohm resistors in parallel, not in series.

questions.question_text: In series combination, Rs = R1 + R2 + ___.
questions.explanation_correct: In a series combination of resistors, the total resistance (Rs) is the sum of the individual resistor values. Since the question asks for the third resistor in the series, the correct answer is R3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula for total resistance in a series combination is Rs = R1 + R2 + R3. The question is asking for the third resistor in the series, so the correct answer is R3. The incorrect answer would be to leave the blank empty, as that would not complete the formula correctly.

questions.question_text: In parallel combination, 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/___.
questions.explanation_correct: In the formula for the equivalent resistance of a parallel combination, 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3, the 'R3' represents the third resistor in the parallel combination. Therefore, the missing term in the given expression is 'R3'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer should be 'R3', as the formula for the equivalent resistance of a parallel combination is 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3. This means that the third resistor in the parallel combination is represented by 'R3' in the equation. The expression 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3 is the correct way to express the parallel combination of resistors.

questions.question_text: In series circuit, the ___ is same through all resistors.
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all the resistors since they are connected one after the other. This is because the current has to flow through each resistor in order to complete the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The resistance is not the same through all resistors in a series circuit. The resistance of the entire circuit is the sum of the individual resistors, as given by the formula Rs = R1 + R2 + R3. The current, on the other hand, is the same through all resistors in a series circuit.

questions.question_text: In parallel circuit, the ___ is same across all resistors.
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the voltage is the same across all resistors because they are all connected directly to the same power source. The current divides among the resistors, but the voltage remains constant throughout the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The current is not the same across all resistors in a parallel circuit. In a parallel circuit, the current divides among the resistors in inverse proportion to their resistance, but the voltage remains the same across all resistors. The correct answer is 'voltage'.

questions.question_text: EMF = Terminal voltage + I x ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The EMF of a cell is equal to the terminal voltage plus the voltage drop across the internal resistance of the cell, which is given by the product of the current and the internal resistance (Ir).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula for EMF of a cell is EMF = Terminal voltage + I x r, where r is the internal resistance of the cell. This is because when current flows through the circuit, there is a voltage drop across the internal resistance of the cell, which reduces the terminal voltage. Therefore, the correct answer to fill in the blank is 'r'.

questions.question_text: Three 9 ohm resistors in series have equivalent resistance of ___ ohms.
questions.explanation_correct: When three 9 ohm resistors are connected in series, the equivalent resistance is the sum of the individual resistances. Since there are three 9 ohm resistors, the total resistance is 9 + 9 + 9 = 27 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If you think the equivalent resistance is not 27 ohms, you may have confused series and parallel connections. In a series connection, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances. Since there are three 9 ohm resistors, the correct answer is 27 ohms.

questions.question_text: Three 9 ohm resistors in parallel have equivalent resistance of ___ ohms.
questions.explanation_correct: When three 9 ohm resistors are connected in parallel, their equivalent resistance (Rp) is calculated using the formula 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3. Substituting the given values, we get 1/Rp = 1/9 + 1/9 + 1/9 = 3/9, which simplifies to Rp = 3 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to add the resistances in parallel, which is not the correct way to find the equivalent resistance. The correct formula to find the equivalent resistance of three resistors in parallel is 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3, where Rp is the equivalent resistance. Plugging in the values, we get 1/Rp = 1/9 + 1/9 + 1/9 = 3/9, which simplifies to Rp = 3 ohms.

questions.question_text: Current in circuit with EMF E and total resistance (R + r) is I = E / ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct formula for the current in a circuit with an EMF E and total resistance (R + r) is I = E / (R + r). This is because the current in the circuit is determined by the EMF (or voltage) and the total resistance, including both the external resistance R and the internal resistance r of the power source.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be I = E / R. This formula is not correct because it does not take into account the internal resistance r of the power source. The current in the circuit is affected by both the external resistance R and the internal resistance r, so the correct formula is I = E / (R + r).

questions.question_text: Two 8 ohm resistors in parallel have equivalent resistance of ___ ohms.
questions.explanation_correct: When two 8 ohm resistors are connected in parallel, the equivalent resistance Rp is given by the formula 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2. Plugging in the values, we get 1/Rp = 1/8 + 1/8 = 2/8 = 1/4. Therefore, the equivalent resistance of the two 8 ohm resistors in parallel is 4 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 16 ohms. This is because when resistors are connected in series, their resistances add up. However, in this case the resistors are connected in parallel, and the formula for equivalent resistance of parallel resistors is the inverse of the sum of the inverses of the individual resistances. Therefore, the correct answer is 4 ohms.

questions.question_text: In series circuit, voltage ___ across resistors.
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all the resistors. Since the voltage drop across each resistor is proportional to its resistance, the voltage gets divided across the different resistors in the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a series circuit, the voltage does not add up across the resistors. Instead, the voltage gets divided across the different resistors in proportion to their resistance values. The accepted answer format is 'divides'.

questions.question_text: In parallel circuit, current ___ across resistors.
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the current divides across the different resistors. This is because the same voltage is applied across all resistors, and the current will flow more through the resistors with lower resistance to minimize the overall resistance in the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'flows' across the resistors. This is not correct because in a parallel circuit, the current divides and flows through the different paths, with each path having a different resistor. The current does not flow the same way as in a series circuit, where the current is the same through all resistors.

questions.question_text: To obtain maximum resistance, resistors should be connected in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: To obtain maximum resistance, resistors should be connected in series. This is because when resistors are connected in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistor values, and this results in the maximum possible resistance in the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To obtain maximum resistance, resistors should not be connected in parallel. When resistors are connected in parallel, the total resistance is less than the smallest individual resistor value, which would not result in the maximum resistance. The correct answer is to connect the resistors in series to obtain the maximum resistance.

questions.question_text: Arrange these combinations of two 6 ohm resistors by equivalent resistance (lowest to highest):
questions.explanation_correct: The equivalent resistance of two 6 ohm resistors in parallel is 3 ohms, which is the lowest of the three combinations. This is because when resistors are in parallel, the total resistance is inversely proportional to the sum of the reciprocals of the individual resistances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Both in series (12 ohm), Single resistor (6 ohm), Both in parallel (3 ohm). This is wrong because when resistors are in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances, which is 12 ohms for two 6 ohm resistors. The single 6 ohm resistor has a higher resistance than the parallel combination of two 6 ohm resistors.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit with 1, 2, and 3 ohm resistors connected to 12V, arrange the resistors by voltage across them (lowest to highest):
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the voltage across each resistor is proportional to its resistance. So, the 1 ohm resistor will have the lowest voltage, followed by the 2 ohm resistor, and then the 3 ohm resistor, which will have the highest voltage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect explanation would be that the voltage across the resistors is equal, since they are in a series circuit. However, this is not the case. The voltage across each resistor is proportional to its resistance, with the 1 ohm resistor having the lowest voltage, the 2 ohm resistor having a higher voltage, and the 3 ohm resistor having the highest voltage.

questions.question_text: In a parallel circuit with 2, 4, and 6 ohm resistors connected to 12V, arrange by current through them (lowest to highest):
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the current divides inversely proportional to the resistance. Therefore, the 2 ohm resistor will have the highest current, followed by the 4 ohm resistor, and the 6 ohm resistor will have the lowest current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect explanation would be to assume that the current is directly proportional to the resistance. This is not true for a parallel circuit, where the current divides inversely proportional to the resistance. The correct order from lowest to highest current is 6 ohm, 4 ohm, and 2 ohm resistors.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to find equivalent resistance of a mixed circuit:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of steps is to first identify the series and parallel groups in the circuit, then calculate the equivalent resistance for the parallel groups using the formula, then add the series resistances to get the final equivalent resistance. This is the logical order to follow as the parallel calculation depends on knowing the individual resistor values, and the final equivalent resistance depends on adding the series resistances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first add the series resistances, without first identifying the series and parallel groups. This is wrong because you need to know which resistors are in series and which are in parallel in order to apply the correct formulas. The correct order is to first identify the groups, then calculate the parallel equivalents, and finally add the series resistances to get the overall equivalent resistance.

questions.question_text: Arrange these circuit conditions by terminal voltage (lowest to highest) for same EMF:
questions.explanation_correct: The terminal voltage is lowest for a short circuit (R = 0) because the current is highest, leading to the largest voltage drop across the internal resistance r of the cell. The terminal voltage is highest for an open circuit (no current) because there is no current flow and no voltage drop across r. The normal load (R = r) has a terminal voltage in between the short circuit and open circuit conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from lowest to highest terminal voltage is: short circuit (R = 0), normal load (R = r), open circuit (no current). This is because as the external resistance R decreases, the current in the circuit increases, leading to a larger voltage drop across the internal resistance r of the cell and a lower terminal voltage. Conversely, as R increases, the current decreases, reducing the voltage drop across r and increasing the terminal voltage.

questions.question_text: How does the equivalent resistance of resistors in series differ from the equivalent resistance of the same resistors in parallel?

options.text: Series equivalent is the sum of resistances; parallel equivalent is always less than the smallest resistance
Series equivalent is less than the smallest; parallel equivalent is the sum
Both are calculated by adding individual resistances
Series equivalent equals parallel equivalent for all combinations

questions.explanation_correct: In series, Rs = R1 + R2 + R3, so the equivalent resistance is always the sum and is greater than any individual resistance. In parallel, 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3, so the equivalent resistance is always less than the smallest individual resistance. This is a fundamental difference between the two connection methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the properties. Series resistance is the sum (always greater than the largest), not less than the smallest. Parallel resistance is always less than the smallest, not the sum. The two methods give very different results for the same set of resistors.

questions.question_text: How does the current distribution differ between a series circuit and a parallel circuit?

options.text: In series, current is the same through all resistors; in parallel, current divides inversely proportional to resistance
In series, current divides; in parallel, current is the same
Current is the same in both series and parallel circuits
In series, current is proportional to resistance; in parallel, current is zero through larger resistors

questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, there is only one path for current, so the same current flows through all resistors. In a parallel circuit, the current from the source splits among the branches, with each branch carrying current inversely proportional to its resistance (I = V/R for each branch, where V is the same for all).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In series, current does not divide  it is the same everywhere. In parallel, current is not the same through all resistors  it varies inversely with resistance. Current is never zero through any resistor in a parallel circuit (unless the resistance is infinite).

questions.question_text: How does the voltage distribution differ between a series circuit and a parallel circuit?

options.text: In series, voltage is the same across all; in parallel, voltage divides
In series, voltage divides proportional to resistance; in parallel, voltage is the same across all
Voltage is the same in both types of circuits
In series, voltage divides inversely to resistance; in parallel, voltage divides proportionally

questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the total voltage divides among resistors in proportion to their resistance (V = IR, and since I is same, V is proportional to R). In a parallel circuit, all resistors are connected across the same two points, so the voltage is the same across all branches.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In series, voltage is not the same  it divides. In parallel, voltage does not divide  it is the same. Voltage divides proportionally (not inversely) to resistance in series. These are complementary properties: what is the same in series (current) divides in parallel, and vice versa.

questions.question_text: How does the terminal voltage of a cell differ from its EMF when current is flowing through the circuit?

options.text: Terminal voltage equals EMF regardless of current
Terminal voltage is less than EMF by the amount Ir (voltage drop across internal resistance)
Terminal voltage is greater than EMF when current flows
Terminal voltage and EMF are unrelated quantities

questions.explanation_correct: When current I flows through a cell with internal resistance r, there is a voltage drop Ir across the internal resistance. The terminal voltage V = E - Ir, which is always less than the EMF (E) when current flows. Only in an open circuit (I = 0) does V = E.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Terminal voltage does not equal EMF when current flows  it is reduced by Ir. Terminal voltage cannot exceed EMF for a discharging cell. EMF and terminal voltage are directly related by V = E - Ir, so they are not unrelated.

questions.question_text: How does the maximum equivalent resistance obtainable from three 4 ohm resistors differ from the minimum equivalent resistance obtainable from the same resistors?

options.text: Maximum is 12 ohms (all in series); minimum is 1.33 ohms (all in parallel)
Maximum is 4 ohms; minimum is 4 ohms
Maximum is 12 ohms; minimum is 4 ohms
Maximum is 8 ohms; minimum is 2 ohms

questions.explanation_correct: Maximum resistance is obtained by connecting all three in series: Rs = 4 + 4 + 4 = 12 ohms. Minimum resistance is obtained by connecting all three in parallel: 1/Rp = 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 = 3/4, so Rp = 4/3 = 1.33 ohms. The ratio of maximum to minimum is 9:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Series gives 12 ohms, not 8 or 4. Parallel gives 4/3 = 1.33 ohms, not 4 or 2. The maximum and minimum are not equal. Series always gives the highest resistance, parallel always gives the lowest for the same set of resistors.

questions.question_text: In a circuit, three resistors carry the same current but have different voltages across them. The voltage across each resistor is proportional to its resistance. These resistors are connected in:
questions.explanation_correct: Same current through all resistors with voltage proportional to resistance (V = IR with same I) is the defining characteristic of a series connection. In parallel, voltage is the same but current differs. The observations described uniquely identify a series connection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In parallel, the voltage is the same across all (not proportional to R), and current differs. A mixed combination would not have the same current through all resistors. The combination of same current + voltage proportional to R is uniquely characteristic of series.

questions.question_text: Three resistors of 2 ohm, 4 ohm, and 6 ohm are connected in a circuit. The voltage across each resistor is 12 V, but the current through the 2 ohm resistor is 6 A, through the 4 ohm is 3 A, and through the 6 ohm is 2 A. These resistors are connected in:
questions.explanation_correct: Same voltage (12 V) across all resistors with current inversely proportional to resistance (6A through 2 ohm, 3A through 4 ohm, 2A through 6 ohm  each satisfying I = V/R) is the defining characteristic of a parallel connection. The current divides, but voltage is shared.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In series, the current would be the same through all resistors, not different. The current values follow I = V/R exactly for each resistor with V = 12V, confirming parallel. A Wheatstone bridge has a specific diamond configuration not described here.

questions.question_text: A circuit has an equivalent resistance of 4 ohms. It contains two 4 ohm resistors in parallel connected in series with a 2 ohm resistor. This circuit is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The circuit contains both series and parallel elements: two 4 ohm resistors in parallel (giving 2 ohms) connected in series with a 2 ohm resistor (giving 2 + 2 = 4 ohms total). This is classified as a mixed or series-parallel combination circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A pure series circuit would have all resistors in one path. A pure parallel circuit would have all resistors across the same two terminals. This circuit has some resistors in parallel and then that combination in series with another resistor, making it a mixed combination.

questions.question_text: A cell has EMF 1.5 V and terminal voltage 1.2 V when delivering current. The difference (0.3 V) represents the voltage drop across the cell's:
questions.explanation_correct: The difference between EMF and terminal voltage (E - V = 1.5 - 1.2 = 0.3 V) equals Ir, the voltage drop across the internal resistance of the cell. This is because V = E - Ir, so E - V = Ir. The internal resistance causes this voltage loss within the cell itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The voltage drop across the external resistance equals the terminal voltage (1.2 V), not the difference. The difference (0.3 V) is specifically the drop across the internal resistance. The cell casing does not create a separate voltage drop. The formula E = V + Ir makes this clear.

questions.question_text: Riya connects three resistors of 2 ohm, 3 ohm, and 5 ohm in series with a 10 V battery in her physics lab. She measures the current using an ammeter. What current reading does Riya observe?
questions.explanation_correct: In series, total resistance Rs = 2 + 3 + 5 = 10 ohms. Current I = V/R = 10/10 = 1 A. This same current of 1 A flows through all three resistors since they are in series. Riya's ammeter will show 1 A regardless of where in the series circuit she places it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total resistance is 10 ohms (not 2, 5, or 1 ohm). Using Ohm's law I = V/R = 10/10 = 1 A. In a series circuit, the current is the same everywhere and equals the total voltage divided by the total resistance.

questions.question_text: Amit connects two resistors of 6 ohm and 3 ohm in parallel across a 12 V battery. He wants to find the total current drawn from the battery. What is the total current?
questions.explanation_correct: In parallel, equivalent resistance Rp = (6 x 3)/(6 + 3) = 18/9 = 2 ohms. Total current I = V/Rp = 12/2 = 6 A. Alternatively: current through 6 ohm = 12/6 = 2 A, current through 3 ohm = 12/3 = 4 A, total = 2 + 4 = 6 A. Both methods give the same answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The parallel resistance is 2 ohms, not 9 ohms or 3 ohms. Using I = V/R = 12/2 = 6 A. The currents through individual branches add up to give the total current from the battery. 2A + 4A = 6A confirms the answer.

questions.question_text: Priya has a cell of EMF 3 V and internal resistance 0.5 ohm. She connects it to an external resistance of 5.5 ohms. She wants to find the terminal voltage across the external resistance. What value does she calculate?
questions.explanation_correct: Current in circuit I = E/(R + r) = 3/(5.5 + 0.5) = 3/6 = 0.5 A. Terminal voltage V = E - Ir = 3 - (0.5 x 0.5) = 3 - 0.25 = 2.75 V. Alternatively, V = IR = 0.5 x 5.5 = 2.75 V. The terminal voltage is less than the EMF due to the internal resistance drop.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 V is the EMF, not the terminal voltage (it would only equal terminal voltage if r = 0 or no current flows). 2.5 V and 0.25 V do not match the calculation. The internal resistance causes a 0.25 V drop, giving V = 3 - 0.25 = 2.75 V.

questions.question_text: Arjun has three 6 ohm resistors. His teacher asks him to connect them to get an equivalent resistance of 4 ohms. How should Arjun connect them?

options.text: Two in parallel, then in series with the third
Two in series, then in parallel with the third

questions.explanation_correct: Two 6 ohm resistors in series give Rs = 6 + 6 = 12 ohms. This 12 ohm combination in parallel with the third 6 ohm resistor gives Rp = (12 x 6)/(12 + 6) = 72/18 = 4 ohms. This is the combination Arjun needs to achieve exactly 4 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All in series gives 18 ohms. All in parallel gives 2 ohms. Two in parallel + one in series gives (3 + 6) = 9 ohms. Only two in series (12 ohms) then in parallel with the third (6 ohms) gives (12 x 6)/(12+6) = 4 ohms.

questions.question_text: Meera connects a 4 ohm and 6 ohm resistor in series with a 20 V battery in her school lab. She wants to find the voltage across the 6 ohm resistor. What value does she get?
questions.explanation_correct: Total resistance = 4 + 6 = 10 ohms. Current I = V/R = 20/10 = 2 A. Voltage across 6 ohm = I x R = 2 x 6 = 12 V. Alternatively, using voltage divider: V6 = (6/10) x 20 = 12 V. The voltage divides in proportion to resistance in a series circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The voltage is not 20 V across the 6 ohm resistor (that is the total battery voltage). Using the voltage divider principle, V6 = (6/(4+6)) x 20 = 12 V. The 4 ohm resistor gets 8 V and the 6 ohm gets 12 V, totalling 20 V.

questions.question_text: Adding more resistors in parallel always decreases the total resistance of the circuit. This is true EXCEPT when:

options.text: The added resistor has very high resistance
The added resistor has infinite resistance (open circuit)
The added resistor is equal to the existing ones
The added resistor has zero resistance

questions.explanation_correct: Adding a resistor with infinite resistance (open circuit) in parallel does not change the total resistance because no current can flow through an infinite resistance branch. Mathematically, 1/Rp = 1/R1 + 1/infinity = 1/R1 + 0, so Rp remains unchanged. For any finite resistance added in parallel, the total resistance always decreases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even a very high resistance added in parallel slightly decreases the total (option A is not an exception). Equal resistors in parallel definitely decrease the total. Zero resistance would short-circuit the combination (total becomes 0). Only infinite resistance has no effect because 1/infinity = 0.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit, removing any one resistor stops current through ALL remaining resistors. In a parallel circuit, this does NOT happen. The reason is that in parallel:

options.text: Removing a parallel branch increases total resistance, so other branches get more current
Each parallel branch provides an independent path, so removing one does not break the path through others
Parallel circuits have no current flowing through individual branches
Removing a branch from parallel has no effect on total resistance

questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, each branch is independently connected across the same two terminals. Removing one branch does not break the circuit for other branches  they continue to operate with the same voltage across them. In series, there is only one path, so removing any resistor breaks the entire circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Removing a parallel branch does change the total resistance (it increases) and total current (it decreases). But the remaining branches continue to function independently. Parallel circuits do have current through each branch. The key point is the independence of parallel paths.

questions.question_text: The terminal voltage of a cell is always less than its EMF. This is true EXCEPT when:

options.text: The external resistance is very large
No current flows through the circuit (open circuit)
The cell is connected to a high-power appliance

questions.explanation_correct: When no current flows (open circuit), V = E - Ir = E - 0 = E. The terminal voltage equals the EMF only when the current is zero, i.e., in an open circuit. For any non-zero current, V < E because of the Ir drop across the internal resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even with a very large external resistance, some current flows and V is slightly less than E. A fully charged cell still has internal resistance. A high-power appliance draws more current, making V much less than E. Only in an open circuit (I = 0) does V exactly equal E.

questions.question_text: Why is the equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel always less than the smallest individual resistance?

options.text: Because parallel connection uses less wire
Because adding parallel paths provides more routes for current flow, reducing overall opposition to current
Because the resistors cancel each other out
Because the voltage across parallel resistors is zero

questions.explanation_correct: Each parallel branch provides an additional path for current to flow. More paths mean less overall opposition to current (lower total resistance). Even the smallest resistor already allows a certain current; adding more paths alongside it allows even more total current for the same voltage, meaning the effective resistance must be even lower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wire length does not determine parallel resistance. Resistors do not cancel each other  they provide additional current paths. The voltage across parallel resistors is the same (not zero). The fundamental reason is that parallel paths increase total current-carrying capacity, reducing effective resistance.

questions.question_text: Why does voltage divide across resistors in a series circuit in proportion to their resistance values?

options.text: Because larger resistors are physically bigger and take up more voltage
Because the same current flows through all resistors, and by Ohm's law V = IR, so the resistor with higher R has higher voltage drop
Because the battery distributes voltage equally to all resistors
Because resistors in series have different currents

questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the current I is the same through every resistor (single path for current). By Ohm's law, V = IR for each resistor. Since I is constant, V is directly proportional to R. A resistor with higher resistance will have a proportionally higher voltage drop across it. This is the voltage divider principle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Physical size has nothing to do with voltage distribution. The battery does not distribute voltage equally  it provides a fixed total EMF. Resistors in series have the same current, not different. The reason is purely Ohm's law applied to each resistor with the same current.

questions.question_text: Why does maximum power transfer occur when the external resistance equals the internal resistance of the cell?

options.text: Because the current is maximum when R = r
Because the terminal voltage is maximum when R = r
Because at R = r, the product of current and terminal voltage (I x V) is maximised, balancing current and voltage optimally
Because the internal resistance becomes zero when R = r

questions.explanation_correct: Power delivered to external resistance P = I^2 x R = [E/(R+r)]^2 x R. When R is very small, current is high but voltage across R is low. When R is very large, voltage is high but current is low. Maximum power occurs at R = r, which is the mathematical optimum where the product of current and external voltage is maximised. This can be proven by calculus (dP/dR = 0 when R = r).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Current is maximum when R = 0 (short circuit), not when R = r. Terminal voltage is maximum when R is infinite (open circuit), not when R = r. Internal resistance does not change  it is a fixed property of the cell. The maximum power transfer theorem is about optimising the balance between current and voltage.
